revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta3) ([[User:Feminist|Feminist]])
revision.text:
{{otherpeople}} {{pp-semi-blp|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2011}} <!--!!! NOTE: TOM KENNY IS NOT DEAD, but was rather the victim of an Internet hoax. DO NOT add a death date for this individual without a reliable source!!!--> {{Infobox person | name = Tom Kenny | image = Tom Kenny FSC 2015.jpg | caption = Kenny at the Florida SuperCon in June 2015 | birth_name = Thomas James Kenny | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1962|7|13}} | birth_place = [[Syracuse, New York]], U.S. | occupation = Actor, comedian | years_active = 1981–present | spouse = {{Marriage|[[Jill Talley]]|1995|}} | children = 2 | parents = | residence = [[Studio City, California]], U.S. }}
'''Thomas James Kenny''' (born July 13, 1962)<!-- http://wtop.com/media-galleries/2017/07/celebrity-birthday-week-july/slide/1/ --> is an American actor and comedian. He is known for voicing the [[SpongeBob SquarePants (character)|title character]] in the ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]'' TV series, video games, and films. Kenny has voiced many other characters including [[Heffer Wolfe]] in ''[[Rocko's Modern Life]]''; the [[Ice King]] in ''[[Adventure Time]]''; the Narrator and Mayor in ''[[The Powerpuff Girls]]''; Carl Chryniszzswics in [[Johnny Bravo]]; Dog in ''[[CatDog]]''; and [[Spyro the Dragon (character)|Spyro]] from the ''[[Spyro (series)|Spyro the Dragon]]'' video game series. His live-action work includes the comedy variety shows ''[[The Edge (Fox TV series)|The Edge]]'' and ''[[Mr. Show]]''. Kenny has won a [[Daytime Emmy Award]] and two [[Annie Award]]s for his voice work as SpongeBob SquarePants and the Ice King.
==Biography== ===Early life and stand-up comedy=== Kenny was born and raised in [[Syracuse, New York]], to Theresa Bridget (Donigan) and Paul Austin Kenny.<ref name=QuickFacts>{{cite web|title=Tom Kenny: Biography|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/tom-kenny/bio/177150|publisher=T.V Guide|accessdate=21 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Tom Kenny, voice of SpongeBob SquarePants, talks of local ties, life in Bikini Bottom|url=http://archives.timesleader.com/2009_49/2009_07_26_26-spongebob.bob_07-26-2009_DCBBFKM_-features.html|website=TimesLeader.com|publisher=Times Leader|accessdate=10 June 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304002139/http://archives.timesleader.com/2009_49/2009_07_26_26-spongebob.bob_07-26-2009_DCBBFKM_-features.html|archive-date=March 4, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> As a young child, he loved drawing and collecting record albums in the late 1960s and 1970s. in Syracuse. He met [[Bobcat Goldthwait]] in first grade and they became life-long friends.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.backstage.com/interview/tom-kenny-finds-his-voice-as-spongebob-squarepants/|title=Tom Kenny Finds his Voice as SpongeBob SquarePants|author=|date=|website=backstage.com|accessdate=June 22, 2017}}</ref><!-- after a teacher, who was displeased with Goldthwait, dragged him into Kenny's class. --> In their mid-teens, they saw an ad for an open-mic night at [[Skaneateles (town), New York|Skaneateles]] that featured comedian [[Barry Crimmins]] with the moniker "Bear Cat". He and Goldthwait went to the event, and performed under the monikers Tomcat and Bobcat, respectively, as a tribute to Crimmins, after which Goldthwait used Bobcat as his stage name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/culture/sarah-larson/barry-crimminss-life-changing-comedy|title=Barry Crimmins’s Life-Changing Comedy|author=|date=|website=The New Yorker|accessdate=June 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.syracuse.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2016/10/barry_crimmins_comedy_special_louis_ck.html|title=Louis C.K. directs CNY comedy legend Barry Crimmins' first-ever standup special|author=|date=|website=syracuse.com|accessdate=June 21, 2017}}</ref><ref name=Parade>{{cite news | last=Wojciechowski | first=Michele | date=April 21, 2015 | title=Voice Artist Tom Kenny on Being SpongeBob SquarePants | publisher=''[[Parade (magazine)|Parade]]'' | url=http://parade.com/392131/michelewojciechowski/voice-artist-tom-kenny-on-being-spongebob-squarepants/ | access-date=July 15, 2016}}</ref> Describing Kenny's stand-up routines, Goldthwait said, "Tom would get up there and talk about his therapist and he didn't even have a therapist, he just loved [[Woody Allen]]."<ref>{{cite news | last=Nieratko | first=Chris | date=September 3, 2015 | title=Bobcat Goldthwait's Latest Documentary Examines Child Sexual Abuse | publisher=''[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]'' | url=https://www.vice.com/read/bobcat-goldthwaits-latest-film-call-me-lucky-193 | access-date=July 15, 2016}}</ref>
Kenny went to [[Bishop Grimes High School]], a Catholic high school,<ref>{{cite web|title=Tom Kenny—Sit Down Shut Up, The Batman, SpongeBob SquarePants—02/27/09|url=http://www.grouchoreviews.com/interviews/285|website=GrouchoReviews.com|publisher=Groucho Reviews|accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref> After college, Kenny performed stand-up comedy around the country for about eight years before he moved on to other venues.<ref name=Parade />
===Television and film career=== Kenny has acted in many films and TV shows, debuting in ''[[How I Got Into College]]'' (1989) and later appeared in films such as ''[[Shakes the Clown]]''<ref>https://www.metro.us/entertainment/interview-tom-kenny-talks-voicing-spongebob-squarepants-and-mr-show/zsJoba---UspN3mmMXb2BE</ref> (1991) and ''[[Comic Book: The Movie]]'' (2004). On television, he would host the "Music News" segments of ''[[Friday Night Videos]]'' in the early 1990s.<!-- brooks and marsh --> He appeared in sketch comedy shows ''[[The Edge (Fox TV series)|The Edge]]'' which aired on Fox from 1992–93, and ''[[Mr. Show]]'' which aired on HBO from 1995 to 1998, both roles in the show were as a regular cast member. He appears in the live-action segments of ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]'' as [[Patchy the Pirate]], appeared on [[R.L. Stine]]'s ''[[R. L. Stine's The Haunting Hour: The Series|The Haunting Hour]]'' on the [[List of R. L. Stine's The Haunting Hour episodes#Season 4: 2014-15|season four episode]], "Uncle Howee" as Uncle Howee, a high-energy kids' show host with strange powers.
===Voice acting=== Kenny said that he voices "a lot of sweet yellow characters for some reason."<ref name="Augustine">{{cite web | url= http://www.staugustine.com/stories/061403/edu_1604752.shtml | title= A discussion with Tom Kenny of 'SpongeBob Squarepants' | work= [[St. Augustine Record]] | first1= Emily | last1= Miller | first2= Elizabeth | last2= Macchione | date= June 14, 2003 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160202193526/http://www.staugustine.com/stories/061403/edu_1604752.shtml | archivedate= February 2, 2016 | df= mdy-all }}</ref> He described [[SpongeBob SquarePants (character)|SpongeBob's]] voice as in between that of a child and an adult, stating "Think a [[Stan Laurel]], [[Jerry Lewis]] kind of child-man. Kind of like a Munchkin but not quite, kind of like a kid, but not in a Charlie Brown child's voice on the TV shows."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cartoonician.com/the-oral-history-of-spongebob-squarepants/|title=The Oral History of SpongeBob SquarePants|date=September 21, 2012|work=cartoonician.com|accessdate=January 2, 2017}}</ref>
[[Joe Murray (animator)|Joe Murray]] auditioned Kenny for voice acting roles for [[Rocko's Modern Life]] in a [[casting call]] in Los Angeles, California.<ref name=Murray>"[http://www.title14.com/rocko/contributors/murray.html Lisa (Kiczuk) Trainor interviews Joe Murray, creator of Rocko's Modern Life]", ''The Rocko's Modern Life FAQ''</ref> On one occasion, the producers required Kenny to fill the role of [[Charlie Adler]], who was absent. He voices Cupid for the Nickelodeon show ''[[The Fairly OddParents]]''.<ref>Lawson, Tim and Alisa Persons. ''The Magic Behind the Voices: A Who's Who of Cartoon Voice Actors''. [https://books.google.com/books?id=0cEAOsLJad8C&pg=PA192&dq=Rocko%27s+Modern+Life&lr=&sig=YINHdozPIw5F0qhgRJ-5SUHaACE p.192].</ref>
Joe Murray chose Kenny for several roles on another one of his projects, ''[[Camp Lazlo]]'' as Scoutmaster Lumpus and Slinkman, because Murray, after seeing Kenny's previous work for ''Rocko's Modern Life,'' felt that Kenny "adds writing to his roles" and "brings so much".<ref name="cn pressroom">[http://turnerinfo.turner.com/presskititem.aspx?P=CARTOON&CID01=98376fcf-3e6c-44a0-aae0-9e41e16079ef&CID02=a97e4cd3-7a0b-4b0c-b126-1a03a9c9ca06Q&A Q & A with Joe Murray] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080123210909/http://turnerinfo.turner.com/presskititem.aspx?P=CARTOON&CID01=98376fcf-3e6c-44a0-aae0-9e41e16079ef&CID02=a97e4cd3-7a0b-4b0c-b126-1a03a9c9ca06Q&A |date=January 23, 2008 }}", ''[[Cartoon Network]] Pressroom''</ref>
He voiced Dog in ''[[CatDog]]'', as well as the voice of Cliff. He voices many characters in ''[[The Powerpuff Girls]]'', including the Mayor, the Narrator, Mitch Mitchelson, Snake, and Little Arturo from the Gangrene Gang, Rainbow the Clown, etc. He voiced Eduardo, and various other characters in ''[[Foster's Home For Imaginary Friends]]'', Dr. Two-Brains in the PBS Kids show, ''[[WordGirl]]'' and the villains Knightbrace, The Common Cold and Mr. Wink in ''[[Codename Kids Next Door]]''.
Kenny is [[The Penguin]] in 2004 TV series ''[[The Batman (TV series)|The Batman]]''.
[[File:Tom Kenny in 2014 at New York Comic Con - Photo by Peter Dzubay.jpg|thumbnail|Kenny at [[New York Comic Con]] in 2014]] He plays a number of roles in the ''[[Transformers Animated]]'' TV show. A few of the characters he voices in this series are [[Starscream]] and his clones, Isaac Sumdac and [[Waspinator]]. Kenny also voiced [[List of Xiaolin Showdown characters|several characters]] on the animated show ''[[Xiaolin Showdown]]'', as well as the [[Autobots]] [[Skids (Transformers)#Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen|Skids]] and [[Wheelie (Transformers)|Wheelie]] in the live-action [[Transformers film series|''Transformers'' film series]]. On ''[[Dilbert (TV series)|Dilbert]]'', Kenny voiced Ratbert, Asok, Dilbert's shower, and some minor characters. He played Mr. Hal Gibson in the animated kids show ''[[Super Robot Monkey Team Hyper Force GO!]]''.
In 2009, Kenny became a regular cast voice in the Fox comedy series ''[[Sit Down, Shut Up (American TV series)|Sit Down, Shut Up]]''. He voices Muhammad Sabeeh "Happy" Fa-ach Nuabar, the secretive custodian who is plotting a terrorist attack, as well as Happy's interpreter. The series premiered on April 19, 2009. [[Kenan Thompson]], [[Kristin Chenoweth]], [[Jason Bateman]], [[Nick Kroll]], [[Cheri Oteri]], [[Henry Winkler]], [[Will Arnett]], and [[Will Forte]] are the other main cast members.<ref name="sdsu">{{cite web| url=http://sitdownshutupwiki.fox.com/?t=anon|title=Sit Down, Shut Up|publisher=Fox|accessdate=April 14, 2009}}</ref>
He plays The Ice King and Magic Man on ''[[Adventure Time]]''. In 2011, Kenny took over the role of [[Rabbit (Winnie-the-Pooh)|Rabbit]] from [[Ken Sansom]] in ''[[Winnie the Pooh (2011 film)|Winnie the Pooh]]''. From 2012–2014, Kenny voiced Woody Johnson on [[Comedy Central]]'s ''[[Brickleberry]]''. He voices Flain, Seismo, and Teslo in ''[[Mixels]]'', Sumo in the Cartoon Network show ''[[Clarence (2014 TV series)|Clarence]]'', Daddo in ''[[Henry Hugglemonster]]'', [[Dr. Otto Octavius]] on ''[[Ultimate Spider-Man (TV series)|The Ultimate Spider-Man]]'', and Leo Callisto in ''[[Miles from Tomorrowland]]''.
He has also provided voices in television advertisements for [[Best Buy]] (as an elf for a Christmas spot), <ref>{{cite web|last=Silver|first=Stephen|title=Best Buy Elf Debuts in Christmas Support Ad|url=http://www.dealerscope.com/article/best-buy-has-debuted-kenneth-blue-elf/1#|publisher=Dealerscope|accessdate=21 September 2012}}</ref> [[Experian]] (as a talking modem alongside [[DC Douglas]]), <ref>{{cite web|last=Douglas|first=DC|title=Experian (w/ Tom Kenny)|url=http://www.dcdouglas.com/experian-tom-kenny/|publisher=DCDouglas.com|accessdate=7 July 2014}}</ref> and Talking Hank in the [[YouTube]] [[web series]] ''[[Talking Tom and Friends (TV series)|Talking Tom and Friends]]''.<ref>{{Citation|last=Talking Tom and Friends|title=Talking Tom and Friends - Meet the Cast|date=2017-01-19|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cnv-rTRSDzI&t=1s|access-date=2018-07-01}}</ref>
In video games, Kenny is best known as the voice of [[Spyro the Dragon (character)|Spyro the Dragon]], having replaced previous voice actor [[Carlos Alazraqui]]. He first voiced Spyro in ''[[Spyro 2: Ripto's Rage!]]'', and continued to voice the character up until ''[[Spyro: A Hero's Tail]]'', where he was replaced by [[Jess Harnell]]. However, he is set to return to voice Spyro in the upcoming ''[[Spyro Reignited Trilogy]]'', a collection of modern remakes of the original Spyro trilogy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Spyro the Dragon is Back in the Spyro Reignited Trilogy!|url=https://blog.activision.com/t5/More-Games/Spyro-the-Dragon-is-Back-in-the-Spyro-Reignited-Trilogy/ba-p/10705007|website=Activision Blog|publisher=Kelly, Kevin|accessdate=7 April 2018}}</ref> He also voiced another character in the series, Sgt. James Byrd, in ''[[Spyro: Year of the Dragon]]''.<ref>{{cite book|title=Spyro: Year of the Dragon Manual|date=October 24, 2000|publisher=Sony Computer Entertainment, Inc|page=18|url=http://www.gamesdatabase.org/Media/SYSTEM/Sony_Playstation/Manual/formated/Spyro-_Year_of_the_Dragon_-_2000_-_Sony_Computer_Entertainment.pdf|accessdate=7 April 2018}}</ref>
====''SpongeBob SquarePants''==== {{Main article|SpongeBob SquarePants}} [[File:Tom Kenny by Gage Skidmore.jpg|thumbnail|left|Kenny in 2010 at [[San Diego Comic Con]]]] While working on the animated series ''[[Rocko's Modern Life]]'', Kenny met marine biologist and animator [[Stephen Hillenburg]], who was also the creative director in the show's fourth season. Hillenburg drew a square sponge that he thought was funny and decided that he had found his character. After the cancellation of ''Rocko's Modern Life'' in 1996, Hillenburg began developing the concept and hired former ''Rocko'' crew members. To voice the character of SpongeBob, Hillenburg approached Kenny. Hillenburg chose the name SpongeBob and used the name SquarePants as a family name that "had a nice ring to it".
The series premiered on May 1, 1999, on [[Nickelodeon]] and became a commercial success in 2000, during its second season. Kenny voices other characters on the show including [[Gary the Snail]], the French narrator (a parody of [[Jacques Cousteau]]), SpongeBob's father Harold SquarePants, and his live-action portrayal of Patchy the Pirate. In 2010, Kenny received the [[Annie Award]] for "Voice Acting in a Television Production" for his role as SpongeBob in ''[[SpongeBob's Truth or Square]]'' (season 6, episode 23-24). He also voiced SpongeBob in the [[SpongeBob SquarePants 2|sequel film]] released on February 6, 2015. In 2018, he received the [[Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Performer in an Animated Program]].<ref>{{cite web|first=Patick|last=Hipes|url=http://deadline.com/2018/04/daytime-creative-arts-emmy-awards-winners-2018-list-1202378665/|title=Daytime Creative Arts Emmy Awards: ‘Bold And The Beautiful’, ‘Sesame Street’ Top Winners|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=April 29, 2018|date=April 27, 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Kenny first met his wife [[Jill Talley]] in 1992 while working on ''The Edge''. The two have also collaborated on HBO's ''[[Mr. Show]]'' and ''SpongeBob SquarePants'', they also both appeared in the music video for "[[Tonight, Tonight (The Smashing Pumpkins song)|Tonight, Tonight]]" by [[The Smashing Pumpkins]]. They have two children, Mack (born c. 1997) and Nora (born August 2003).<ref name=QuickFacts/><ref name=HipSquare>{{cite web|last=Edwards|first=Ellen|title=As the voice of SpongeBob, Tom Kenny knows it's hip to be square|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2004-11-30/features/0411300350_1_spongebob-and-patrick-voice-tom-kenny|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=November 30, 2004}}</ref> The Kennys live in [[Studio City, California]].<ref>http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2015/01/tom_kenny_spongebob_squarepants_east_syracuse.html</ref>
==Awards and nominations== {|class="wikitable" ; |- style="text-align:center;" ! style="background:#ccc;" | Year ! style="background:#ccc;" | Award ! style="background:#ccc;" | Category ! style="background:#ccc;" | Film/TV Show ! style="background:#ccc;" | Result |- | 2001 || rowspan="2"| [[Annie Award]] || Best Outstanding Individual Achievement for Voice Acting by a Male Performer in an Animated Television Production || rowspan="2"| ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]'' || {{Nom}} |- | 2008 || Best Voice Acting in an Animated Television Production || {{Nom}} |- | rowspan="2"| 2010 || [[Golden Raspberry Awards]] || Worst Screen Couple <small>(shared with [[Shia LaBeouf]] and either [[Megan Fox]] or any "Transformer")</small>|| ''[[Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen]]'' || {{Nom}} |- | [[Annie Award]] || Best Voice Acting in an Animated Television Production || ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]'' || {{Won}} |- | 2011 || [[Golden Raspberry Awards]] || Worst Screen Ensemble <small>(shared with the entire cast)</small> || ''[[Transformers: Dark of the Moon]]'' || {{Nom}} |- | 2014 || [[Annie Award]] || Outstanding Achievement, Voice Acting in an Animated TV/Broadcast Production || ''[[Adventure Time]]'' || {{Won}} |- | 2015 || [[Annie Award]] || Voice Acting in an Animated Feature || ''[[The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water]]'' || {{Nom}} |- | 2018 || [[Daytime Emmy Award]] || [[Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Performer in an Animated Program|Outstanding Performer in an Animated Program]] || ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]'' || {{Won}} |}
==Filmography== {{Main article|Tom Kenny filmography}} {{columns-list|colwidth=18em| * ''[[How I Got into College]]'' (1989) * ''[[Shakes the Clown]]'' (1992) * ''[[Plughead Rewired: Circuitry Man II]]'' (1994) <!-- NEED SOURCE * ''[[Jimmy Neutron: Boy Genius (film)|Jimmy Neutron: Boy Genius]]'' (2001) --> * ''[[Dr. Dolittle 2]]'' (2001) * ''[[The Powerpuff Girls Movie]]'' (2002) * ''[[Adam Sandler's Eight Crazy Nights]]'' (2002) * ''[[Run Ronnie Run]]'' (2002) <!-- TV MOVIE: * ''[[Windy City Heat]]'' (2003) --> <!-- NEED SOURCE * ''[[My Life with Morrissey]]'' (2003) --> <!-- NEED SOURCE * ''[[Scary Movie 3]]'' (2003) --> * ''[[The SpongeBob SquarePants Movie]]'' (2004) <!-- NEED SOURCE * ''[[Comic Book: The Movie]]'' (2004) --> * ''[[Surviving Christmas]]'' (2004) <!-- NEED SOURCE * ''[[Lil Pimp]]'' (2005) --> * ''[[Hoodwinked]]'' (2005) <!-- NEED SOURCE * ''[[Sky High (2005 film)|Sky High]]'' (2005) --> * ''[[Ant Bully (film)|Ant Bully]]'' (2006) * ''[[Idiocracy]]'' (2006)<ref>http://www.screenjunkies.com/movies/movie-news/7-other-places-you-ve-heard-tom-kenny-the-voice-of-spongebob</ref> * ''[[Meet the Robinsons]]'' (2007) * ''[[Happily N'Ever After]]'' (2007) * ''[[Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen]]'' (2009) * ''[[World's Greatest Dad]]'' (2009) * ''[[Winnie the Pooh (2011 film)|Winnie the Pooh]]'' (2011) * ''[[Transformers: Dark of the Moon]]'' (2011) * ''[[God Bless America (film)|God Bless America]]'' (2011) * ''[[Frankenweenie (2012 film)|Frankenweenie]]'' (2012) * ''[[Hotel Transylvania]]'' (2012) * ''[[Zambezia (film)|Zambezia]]'' (2012) * ''[[Back to the Sea]]'' (2012) * ''[[I Know That Voice]]'' (2013) * ''[[The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water]]'' (2015) * ''[[Ant-Man (film)|Ant-Man]]'' (2015) <!-- UPCOMING * ''[[Transformers: The Last Knight]]'' (2017 upcoming) --> <!-- UPCOMING: * ''[[The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature]]'' (2017 upcoming) --> }}
